I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
programmatic approach for the Strengthening Economic Management Reform Program1 and (ii) 
a proposed policy-based grant to the Republic of Kiribati for subprogram 1 of the Strengthening 
Economic Management Reform Program. 
 
2.  The program aims to strengthen Kiribati’s economic management and create a more 
stable macroeconomic framework. The programmatic approach, with one subprogram each in 
2017 and 2018, will build on current government-led reforms supported by a multi-partner policy 
action matrix.2 The improved (i) management of public finances, assets, and liabilities; and (ii) 
economic environment for the private sector align with the Kiribati Development Plan (KDP), 
2016–2019 and the Kiribati Economic Reform Program (KERP).3 
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Development  challenges.  One  of  the  most  remote  and  geographically  dispersed 
countries in the world, Kiribati has 33 islands spread over 5 million square kilometers of ocean, 
an area larger than India. Its major export commodities are copra and fish. The capital, Tarawa, 
is about 4,000 kilometers from the major trade markets of Australia, Hawaii, and New Zealand. 
The population of about 116,000 people lives on 20 coral atolls and a single volcanic island with 
a land area of less than 800 square kilometers. Kiribati’s low-lying atolls rise little more than 1.8 
meters above sea level on average and are therefore at the forefront of climate change. About 
50,000 people live on Tarawa, which has a land area of 16 square kilometers, while the islet of 
Betio is as densely populated as Manila or Jakarta. This extreme remoteness and large dispersion 
create significant service delivery challenges. 
 
4.  Kiribati is vulnerable to external shocks because of its geographic characteristics; high 
exposure to the negative effects of climate change, including rising sea levels; high import 
dependency; and heavy reliance on income from external sources such as investment income 
from its sovereign wealth fund, the Revenue Equalization Reserve Fund (RERF). Private sector 
development has been constrained by high business, investment, and connectivity costs. The 
public sector plays a dominant role in the economy, crowding out private sector activities through 
state-owned  enterprises  (SOEs)  that  operate  in  potentially  competitive  sectors. 4 Without 
independent monetary and exchange rate policies, given the adoption of the Australian dollar, 
and the limited leverage of banking regulation and interest rate policy, the government is reliant 
on fiscal policy to manage the impact of shocks and stimulate inclusive growth.

5.  Recent economic and fiscal performance. Despite these challenges, Kiribati grew 3.5% 
per year during 2011–2015 (Figure 1), buoyed by development partner financed investments in 
roads and waste and sanitation, as Kiribati seeks to overcome significant infrastructure deficit; 
and fishing license revenues, which reached nearly A$200 million or 96% of gross domestic 
product (GDP) in 2015.5 Over the same period, tax revenue stagnated at 14%–17% of GDP 
because of the narrow tax base, weak tax compliance, and poor corporate tax performance of 
SOEs. On the public expenditure side, the public sector wage bill has remained relatively flat at 
24%–28% of GDP, reflecting government efforts to restrain current expenditure. In 2016, because 
of unfavorable weather conditions, fishing license revenues fell more than 40% to A$116 million 
(55% of GDP). This reduced a fiscal surplus of 47.7% of GDP in 2015 to a deficit of 12.4% of 
GDP in 2016. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) anticipates that growth is expected to pick 
up to 3.1% in 2017, although fiscal deficits of 7.8% in 2017 and 5.6% in 2018 are projected as 
fishing revenues continue to decline from their 2015 peak (Figure 2). The IMF considers Kiribati 
to be at high risk of debt distress because of weak growth prospects and the long-term threat of 
climate change.6

6.  Medium-term fiscal path. Although Kiribati’s fiscal position stabilized during 2014–2015 
(Table 1), the government recognizes that limited capacity to take on new debt, volatility of fishing 
revenue, severe infrastructure deficits (particularly on the outer islands), and the negative effects 
of climate change mean that it must remain vigilant and continue efforts to build fiscal buffers and 
secure support from development partners for project and policy financing. Efforts to improve 
domestic  revenue  mobilization  have  helped  expand  the  tax  net,  improve  compliance,  and

increase collections. The government introduced a value-added tax in mid-2014 to replace 
distortive  tariffs  and  trade  taxes.  Increased  public  expenditure  has  been  driven  by  large 
infrastructure projects financed by development partners, increases in health and education

A$17.2 million in the 2016 budget.7 Future budget decisions will need to account for a prudent 
assessment of Kiribati’s spending goals, revenue projections, and the management targets of the 
RERF. Maintaining a sustainable budget position in the medium term will be central to this effort, 
based on fishing revenue projections that allow the government to protect its public expenditure 
programs from potential revenue volatility, complemented by an appropriately sized cash reserve 
buffer to deal with external shocks.

7.  Government  reform  priorities.  A  more  stable  macroeconomic  framework  is  the 
overarching objective of the KDP, 2016–2019 and the KERP (footnote 3). The KERP was 
developed against a backdrop of weak economic management, unsustainable drawdowns from 
the RERF, high levels of non-concessional debt, uncoordinated borrowing by ministries made 
without approval from the Ministry of Finance and Economic Development (MFED), poorly 
                                                
7  The copra subsidy is the government’s main form of income redistribution and social welfare to the outer islands, 
where job creation and income-earning opportunities are limited. At the government’s request, the World Bank is 
undertaking a review of potential efficient and equitable alternatives to the copra subsidy, including exploring cash-
for-work  opportunities,  recalibrating  the  eligibility  criteria  for  existing  social  protection  schemes,  adjusting 
postsecondary scholarships, and providing transport grants to seamen for boarding foreign vessels.

4 
performing SOEs, and weak management of fisheries revenues.8 Budget support through policy 
dialogue and policy financing from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and other development 
partners has helped the government prioritize, appropriately sequence, and implement the KERP. 
The KERP emphasizes (i) improving public financial management, (ii) improving the management 
of public assets and liabilities, and (iii) creating an environment for private sector-led growth. 
 
8.  Development partner coordination. The Economic Reform Taskforce (ERT), chaired by 
the secretary to the cabinet, is the main forum for consultation and coordination between the 
government and development partners on the implementation of the KERP. The ERT comprises 
representatives from the MFED; implementing agencies such as the Ministry of Fisheries and 
Marine Resources Development; the Ministry of Commerce, Industry and Cooperatives; the 
Ministry of Information, Communication, Transport, and Tourism Development; and development 
partners. The ERT meetings provide a forum for facilitating dialogue, monitoring progress, and 
coordinating technical assistance (TA). Other avenues for collaboration and coordination include 
the annual IMF Article IV consultations and the biennial Development Partners Forum. 
 
9.  ADB collaborated closely with the World Bank and the governments of Australia and New 
Zealand in preparing this program, which uses a joint government-led policy matrix to underpin 
the provision of budget support.9 The joint matrix includes actions used as triggers by other 
development  partners  such  as  procurement,  fisheries,  asset  management,  and 
telecommunications reforms. This, along with other complementary measures such as joint 
missions, reduces transaction costs for the government while increasing the policy impact. In 
addition, ADB and the World Bank consulted the Japan International Cooperation Agency and 
the IMF and its Pacific Financial Technical Assistance Centre to coordinate policy advice and TA, 
particularly in fisheries revenue and public finance management (PFM). 
 
10.  Government reform  progress. This collaboration  and  coordination  has  helped  the 
government focus its efforts on accomplishing the three pillars of KERP (para. 7). During 2013–
2016, the government (i) completed an analysis of public expenditure patterns, whose findings 
informed the preparation of the government’s annual fiscal strategy; (ii) completed external audits 
of the 2015 financial statements of operational SOEs with debts or guaranteed overdraft facilities; 
(iii) ceased government bailouts for SOEs and payments to the Australia and New Zealand 
Banking Group Limited (ANZ Bank), the only commercial bank in Kiribati, under guarantee of 
overdrafts and loans; (iv) approved a national fisheries policy to strengthen resource management 
and maximize license revenues; (v) enacted tax legislation to improve compliance and introduced 
a value-added tax to broaden the revenue base; (vi) improved management of contingent 
liabilities;  (vii)  approved  and  implemented  a  debt  policy  to  prevent  new  non-concessional 
borrowing; (ix) appointed new asset managers for the RERF and restructured the RERF portfolio; 
and (x) privatized a government-owned telecommunications company and granted a second 
mobile operator a license to operate.10 
 
                                                
8  Between 2013–2016, the government has taken important measures to improve fiscal management of debt policy. 
Kiribati has adopted a debt policy establishing criteria for concessional and non-concessional public borrowing and 
formal procedures for contracting new debt, consistent with sustainable macroeconomic management. It has also 
improved the management of public debt by establishing a comprehensive database of public debt. Kiribati’s current 
debt portfolio constitutes external debt only—from ADB and Taipei,China—since all domestic debt was cleared in 
2015. There is no SOE debt, and none of the SOEs have overdraft facilities with the Australia and New Zealand 
Banking Group Limited (ANZ Bank). 
9  Joint Policy Matrix (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
10 ADB. 2016. Finding Balance 2016: Benchmarking the Performance of State-Owned Enterprises in Island Countries. 
Manila.

5 
11.  ADB value addition. ADB has played a critical role in (i) identifying critical SOE, PFM, 
and business environment reforms to support the government’s reform agenda; (ii) enhancing 
development coordination through coordinating and collaborating with other development partner 
initiatives in these areas; (iii) providing TA support for capacity building and reform implementation, 
particularly for SOE reform;11 and (iv) collaborating with the governments of Australia and New 
Zealand to support the restructure of the Public Utilities Board (PUB),12 complementing ongoing 
project investments in water, sanitation, and energy. Given thin administrative capacity, the 
government’s focus on addressing significant deterioration in infrastructure assets, and the need 
to improve service delivery to the outer islands, reform implementation would have been difficult 
and have major cost implications without ADB technical, strategic, and financial support provided 
under this program. This support aligns with the KDP and the KERP. It is consistent with the 
Pacific Approach, 2016–2020 and its focus on reducing the costs of doing business and providing 
social services, managing risks from natural and economic shocks, and enabling value creation 
by supporting private sector growth and investment.13 The programmatic approach provides for 
an ongoing, coordinated multi-development partner dialogue on critical economic reform issues, 
which also acts to situates partner support within the government’s economic reform priorities. At 
the same time the program grant enables government to finance reform efforts and build a broader 
support  base  for  these  actions.  Future  ADB  support  will  continue  to  support  reform 
implementation in the three major reform areas identified in the KERP (para. 7). The TA will further 
support economic management, structural reforms, and PFM (footnote 10). 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
12.  In line with the KDP, the impact of the program will be stable macroeconomic framework 
achieved. The outcome will be overall economic management improved. 
 
C.  Outputs 
 
13.  The program has two outputs supported by the two subprograms. The policy reform 
actions that make up the program policy matrix are a subset of the joint policy matrix (footnote 8) 
that is monitored by the Economic Reform Taskforce. Each development partner has selected 
areas from the matrix that it directly supports, including the approval of a public procurement 
reform plan, the approval of a fisheries joint venture plan, and the issuance of a second mobile 
operator license. 
 
14.  The government has completed all six actions under subprogram 1, which are outlined in 
paras. 15–17. 
 
15.  Output 1. Management of public finances, assets, and liabilities improved. These 
reforms will contribute to wider improvements in the maintenance of fiscal sustainability, the 
containment of fiscal risks, and overall PFM. They include the following:

(i)  Assets. Under subprogram 1, the government completed a review of its RERF 
custodial arrangements to ensure that the services of the current provider remain 
competitive  with  current  market  practice  and  benchmarks.  The  government 
subsequently endorsed the recommendations of the review and approved the 
issuance of a request for proposal for custodial services, which was issued in April 
2017. Subprogram 2 will ensure the contract for custodial services is awarded 
based on the completed selection and evaluation process. 
 
(ii)  Contingent liabilities. The implementation of a public sector debt database has 
enabled the government to better monitor all debt, including contingent liabilities. 
The  program’s  focus  on  the  considerable  audit  backlog  resulted  in  the 
government’s recognition of this priority issue. Despite constrained capacity, the 
government  is  now  addressing the  backlog. The government  has  completed 
financial  statements  for  2016  for  five  major  SOEs:  Air  Kiribati  Limited, 
Development Bank of Kiribati, Kiribati Oil Company Ltd, Kiribati Ports Authority, 
and the PUB. The Kiribati Provident Fund also completed financial statements for 
2012–2016. Subprogram 2 will ensure financial statements for 2017 are completed 
and, in the case of the Kiribati Provident Fund, submitted to the Kiribati National 
Audit Office. 
 
(iii)  Public finance management. The government has identified the shortcomings of 
its financial  management  information  system  (FMIS),  including  its  inability  to 
prepare, execute, or report against the national budget, which undermines financial 
control, monitoring, and reporting. The government has approved a full review to 
assess  the  needs  and  identify  all  gaps  in  the  FMIS.  The  government  has 
committed $2.5 million in its 2018 budget to improve or replace the FMIS in 
subprogram 2, based on the outcome of the full review. 
 
(iv)  State-owned enterprises. On 30 August 2017, the cabinet, supported by ADB, 
approved to seek a concession plus lease arrangement for the government-owned 
Captain Cook Hotel on Kiritimati island. Subprogram 2 will build on this support to 
prepare  the  Captain  Cook  Hotel  for  the  transaction,  including  through  an 
advertisement for sale and any necessary road shows, and then reach cabinet 
approval to execute the concession agreement. The hotel has had mixed financial 
results since 2010. In late 2015, after 2 years of poor financial performance and 
the hotel failing to remit pension and income tax deductions from staff salaries, the 
government directed the MFED and an ADB-funded TA team to explore public–
private partnership (PPP) arrangements. 
 
16.  Output 2. Environment for the private sector improved. Private sector-led growth is 
an important focus for the government, and the program will support the following reforms: 
 
(i)  Improving access to basic utilities. Access to reliable and responsibly costed 
electricity and water is vital to encourage the growth of the private sector. Following 
the appointment of a new chief executive officer, the PUB began implementing a 
medium-term reform plan. The reforms are intended to ensure operationally and 
financially  sustainable  delivery  of  electricity,  water,  and  sanitation  services. 
Changes to electricity tariffs in January 2017 and to residential connection fees in 
April 2017 to make electricity more affordable and accessible to lower-income 
households have resulted in expanded access to power and an increased billing 
collection rate. For example, charges for the first 100 kilowatt-hours (kWh) of

7 
consumption were reduced from A$0.40 per kWh to A$0.10 per kWh for domestic 
consumers. The charge for consuming 100–300 kWh of electricity is A$0.40 per 
kWh, but the rate for more than 300kWh of consumption increased from A$0.40 
per kWh to A$0.55 per kWh. The cabinet has also approved a reduction in the 
household electricity connection fee from A$380 to A$50, which prompted more 
than  1,000  households  to  request  electricity  connections.  Subprogram  2  will 
support further reform in the PUB to include water and sanitation services. The 
PUB aims to deliver piped water that is available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week 
through a pressurized system. Although water is free, PUB research suggests that 
even poor households would be prepared to pay a usage fee to have a regular 
supply of piped water rather than water being available only from communal 
standpipes for 2 hours a day, every second day. 
 
(ii)  Public–private  partnership  concessions.  The  government  awarded  a  PPP 
concession for the Betio Shipyard Limited. The government owns Betio Shipyard 
and chose to tender out the lease of the shipyard and its assets under a PPP 
concession  agreement,  for  an  anticipated  term  of  25  years.  In  return,  the 
concession  holder  will  be  required  to  operate  the  shipyard,  pay  an  annual 
concession fee, repair the existing slipway, and construct a new slipway with larger 
capacity to service the fishing fleet rather than have these vessels serviced in Suva, 
Fiji. Subprogram 2 will also support the award of a management contract for the 
government-owned flagship hotel, Otintaai Hotel. 
 
17.  Subprogram 2 building on subprogram 1. The policy matrix sets out 8 proposed policy 
actions for subprogram 2, with completion expected October 2018. Subprogram 2 will extend the 
focus of  the policy actions under subprogram 1 to include (i) the development of a whole-of-
government  asset  management  strategy;  (ii)  the  implementation  of  a  community  service 
obligation policy in 2018 that will result in SOEs and utilities being directly paid for the assessed 
cost of providing agreed community services rather than a reliance on ad hoc cash injections, 
which have been an unpredictable drain on budget resources; (iii) the continuation of PUB reforms, 
focusing on the cost and quality of water and sanitation services and delivery of services to the 
most vulnerable groups; and (iv) the creation of a PPP for the Otintaai Hotel.  
 
D.  Development Financing Needs 
 
18.  The Government of Kiribati has requested a grant not exceeding $5.0 million from ADB’s 
Special Funds resources (Asian Development Fund) for Subprogram 1. Subprogram 2 financing 
is $2.5 million. The grant will (i) help meet the financing gap for the 2017 fiscal year and (ii) 
incentivize timely implementation of the KERP policy reform actions needed to move toward fiscal 
sustainability in the long term. The government forecasts its financing requirements to be $18.7 
million in 2017 (9.2% of GDP) and $15.4 million in 2018 (7.3% of GDP). 
 
19.  Budget support will help insulate public spending from potential volatility in fishing revenue, 
limit drawdowns from the RERF and allow for its growth, and allow the government to move 
toward structurally balanced budgets over the medium term. ADB, the governments of Australia 
and New Zealand, and the World Bank jointly support the implementation of the KERP, with these 
partners providing collaborative cofinancing of $0.4 million (Australia), $2.0 million (New Zealand), 
and $5.0 million (World Bank). Total policy financing of $12.4 million will help finance 69% of the 
recurrent fiscal deficit.

8 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
20.  The program is expected to be implemented over 24 months from November 2016- 
October 2018. The implementation period for subprogram 1 is November 2016–May 2018. The 
MFED, as the executing agency, will oversee implementation of agreed policy actions and be 
responsible for program administration, disbursements, and maintenance of all records. The 
implementing agencies will be the MFED; the Ministry of Fisheries and Marine Resources 
Development;  the  Ministry  of  Infrastructure  and  Sustainable  Energy;  and  the  Ministry  of 
Information, Communication, Transport, and Tourism Development. TA from ADB and other 
partners has been, and will continue to be, available to support the government in accomplishing 
the policy actions. Procurement, advance contracting, and retroactive financing are not expected. 
ADB will disburse the grant proceeds following ADB’s Loan Disbursement Handbook (2017, as 
amended from time to time). ADB will carry out joint progress monitoring through the joint ERT. 
 
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Economic and Financial 
 
21.  The  primary  gain  from  strengthening  the  RERF  management  is  improved  fiscal 
sustainability and macroeconomic stability. The RERF is the primary vehicle for intergenerational 
saving and buffers the economy from external shocks and revenue volatility, which tends to be 
dominated by the fishing license fee revenue. The improvement of the RERF management will 
enhance the government’s ability to address these shocks while maintaining vital public services 
and infrastructure investments. Better public debt monitoring will also contribute to an improved 
fiscal position. The expected impact of the PUB restructuring includes the improved health of 
Kiribati’s population, especially those in Tarawa, through enhanced access to improved sanitation 
infrastructure and services. Improved access to water and electricity is also expected to create 
business opportunities and foster private sector development in the country. 
 
B.  Governance 
 
22.  Promoting  good  governance  is  a  key  national  priority.  The  2010  Public  Financial 
Management Performance Report identified relative strengths in Kiribati’s PFM. The report also 
highlighted weaknesses, including oversight of aggregate fiscal risk from other public sector 
entities; multiyear perspective in fiscal planning; recording and management of cash balances, 
debt, and guarantees; and competition, value for money, and controls in procurement.14 Through 
the KERP, the government has been making steady progress in addressing these reforms (para. 
9).  In  addition,  the  government  has  strengthened  expenditure  controls  through  improved 
accounting systems. Kiribati’s annual budget is publicly available on the government’s website. 
In addition, the government completed an ADB-supported public procurement review in August 
2017,15 which concluded that Kiribati’s public procurement process, under its Procurement Act, 
2002, is outdated and incomplete. ADB is working closely with the government and other partners 
to implement the Kiribati Public Procurement Reform Program, which will, in the long term, reduce 
staff costs; improve value for money, quality, and delivery of purchases; and lead to 10%–15% in 
overall savings.16 ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and 
discussed with the government and the MFED. 
                                                
14 Government of Kiribati. Public Financial Management Performance Report. Unpublished; and Government of Kiribati. 
Public Financial Management (PFM) Reform Plan, 2011–2014. Unpublished. 
15 ADB. 2013. Technical Assistance for Pacific Economic Management (Phase 2). Manila. 
16 ADB. 2014. Technical Assistance for Sector and Thematic Analyses in Policy Development. Manila.

9 
C.  Poverty and Social 
 
23.  A focus on the improvement in the management of public finances, assets, and liabilities 
along with strong SOE reform will benefit the poor and vulnerable in Kiribati directly by improving 
public services and indirectly by enabling the government to better develop and implement its 
budget, inclusive of social programs. Improved economic management can free up resources that 
will allow the government to better respond to external shocks, increase allocations to social 
sectors, and enable private sector job creation. 
 
D.  Safeguards 
 
24.  The program is classified category C for the environment, involuntary resettlement, and 
indigenous  peoples.  SDCC  has  reviewed  the  environmental  and  social  implications  of  the 
program outputs and actions, and no activity will result in or lead to any physical works or 
infrastructure.  The  program  will  therefore  not  cause  any  involuntary  resettlement  and 
environmental impacts. No distinct and vulnerable groups of indigenous peoples will be affected. 
 
E.  Risks and Mitigation Measures 
 
25.  Major risks and mitigation measures are summarized in Table 2 and described in detail in 
the risk assessment and risk management plan.17

IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
 
26.  The government has assured ADB that implementation of the program shall conform to 
all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption measures, safeguards, 
gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail in the grant 
documents. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
27.  I am satisfied that the proposed programmatic approach and policy-based grant would 
comply with the Articles of Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend 
that the Board approve: 
(i)  the programmatic approach for the Strengthening Economic Management Reform 
Program, and 
 
(ii)  the grant not exceeding $5,000,000 to the Republic of Kiribati from ADB’s Special 
Funds  resources  (Asian  Development  Fund)  for  subprogram  1  of  the 
Strengthening Economic Management Reform Program, on terms and conditions 
that  are  substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft  grant 
agreement presented to the Board.
